subject: Re: [junit] Chaining of rules
msgSnippet: The lack of order of rules is by design. Rules are intended to be composeable and order-independent. I would need a compelling use case to tighten this

The lack of order of rules is by design. Rules are intended to be composeab=
le and order-independent. I would need a compelling use case to tighten thi=
s constraint.

Kent

On Jul 30, 2011, at 1:33 AM, stefan.birkner wrote:

> =
Hello,
> sometimes you care about the order of rules. Therefore I created a=
 RuleChain, which is a rule itself:
> 
> @Rule
> public TestRule chain =3D =
RuleChain.outerRule(new FirstRule()).enclose(new SecondRule());
> 
> What d=
o you thing about the naming outerRule and enclose?
> 
> What do you think =
about starting with the outer rule instead of starting with the inner rule:=

> 
> @Rule
> public TestRule chain =3D RuleChain.innerRule(new SecondRule(=
)).enclosedBy(new FirstRule());
> 
> If you want to see the code, look at h=
ttps://github.com/stefanbirkner/junit/commit/3584c44bedd8705f30dda4f4213fa4=
5655b998c7
> The issue is https://github.com/KentBeck/junit/issues/193
